title: Angular momentum cons - bar rod sphere and spring

content.question:

Figures <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> are top views of a system that can rotate in a horizontal plane about a vertical axis through a fixed pivot. One end of a uniform, thin bar is attached to the pivot, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. A small sphere is attached to a rod of negligible mass, and the other end of the rod is attached to the pivot. A compressed spring is between the sphere and the free end of the bar, and the bar and sphere are initially held in place.

The bar has mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>, length <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>ℓ</mo></math>, and rotational inertia <math alttext="one third M times l squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></math> about the pivot. The sphere has the same mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> as the bar, and its center is a fixed distance <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>ℓ</mo></math> from the pivot.

At time <math alttext="lowercase t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the bar and sphere are released, after which the bar and rod start rotating with negligible friction about the pivot point, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. At a later time <math alttext="lowercase t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, the bar and rod are <math alttext="180" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>180</mn></math> degrees apart. At <math alttext="lowercase t equals lowercase t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, a mechanism locks the bar and rod together so that they maintain a relative angle of <math alttext="180" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>180</mn></math> degrees, but are still free to rotate about the pivot as a unit.

(a) 

i. Indicate whether the bar-rod-sphere system rotates clockwise, counterclockwise, or not at all after the mechanism has locked the bar and rod together. Justify your answer.

At time <math alttext="lowercase t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the bar and sphere are released, after which the bar and rod start rotating with negligible friction about the pivot point, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. At a later time <math alttext="lowercase t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, the bar and rod are <math alttext="180" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>180</mn></math> degrees apart. At <math alttext="lowercase t equals lowercase t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, a mechanism locks the bar and rod together so that they maintain a relative angle of <math alttext="180" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>180</mn></math> degrees, but are still free to rotate about the pivot as a unit.

(a) 

i. Indicate whether the bar-rod-sphere system rotates clockwise, counterclockwise, or not at all after the mechanism has locked the bar and rod together. Justify your answer.

Assume that the bar and rod are approximately parallel at <math alttext="lowercase t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and that the spring takes a very short amount of time to push them apart.

ii. Derive the value of the angle <math alttext="theta sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> through which the bar rotates from its starting position to where the bar and rod become locked together.

The spring that causes the initial separation of the two pieces exerts a force on each piece for a short time interval <math alttext="Zero is less than or equal to lowercase t, which is less than or equal to lowercase t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, after which the sphere has an angular speed <math alttext="omega sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></math>. The force results in a torque about the pivot, and the magnitude <math alttext="tau" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>τ</mi></math> of the torque exerted on the sphere by the spring, as a function of time, can be modeled by the following equation:

where <math alttext="tau sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> is a positive constant.
(b) Derive an expression for <math alttext="lowercase t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> in terms of <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>ℓ</mo></math>, <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>, <math alttext="tau sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="omega sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.
